column1: rotomfortunae 159029356313 "2017-03-31 06:22:16 GMT" https://rotomfortunae.tumblr.com/post/159029356313/transgender-wwii-veteran-comes-out-as-a-woman-at "transqueermediaexchange:  A transgender World War II veteran proves it’s never too late to live life truthfully. Patricia Davies
column2: from Leicestershire
column4: didn’t decide to transition into a female until she turned 90 years old. Davies — born Peter — has known she was a woman since she was just a toddler. “I’ve known I was transgender since I was 3 years old. I knew a girl called Patricia
column5: and I decided I wanted to be known by that name but it didn’t stick
column6: ” Davies told Caters News Agency. Davies kept her identity a secret for most of her life for fear she would be shunned by her peers or forced to undergo electric shock treatment. “The atmosphere [around being transgender] was not safe. People did not understand what transgender was
column7: ” Davies said. Davies — who served in the army between April 1945 and 1948 — said coming out as transgender would have categorized her as a homosexual
column8: which wouldn’t have been accepted in the army. Despite losing friends and cheating death while serving in the armed forces
column9: she says she’s glad she got to have the experience. “I feel quite proud having served during the war and having done military service
column10: in particular during the trouble in Palestine
column13: eventually came out to her supportive wife in 1987. Her wife
column14: to whom she was married for 63 years
column15: bought Davies jewelry and dresses that she could wear in private. Sadly
column16: her wife passed away six years ago. “I was 60 when it all came pouring out to my wife
column17: she was very sympathetic and helped me all the way
column18: but we agreed to keep it quiet
column20: who first learned about transgender identity from a TV show sometime in the 1970s. When Davies first came out to her wife
column21: she decided to wear high heels but was deterred when teenagers saw her and threw eggs at her window. Now a nonagenarian
column22: Davies has begun taking estrogen to move her transition forward and has come out to her community. “It feels like a weight has been lifted off my shoulders. I was living a lie
column23: ” she told Caters. “I have been keeping quiet. I have slowly started to tell some of my neighbors. Everybody said
column26: ‘” she added. Patricia was inspired to make the big change from male to female after seeing the romantic comedy film “Boy Meets Girl
column27: ” which features transgender characters. Now that transgender people are portrayed often in film and on TV
column28: Davies feels more comfortable being herself. “It’s not 100 percent safe now but it’s much better than it was. People that I have told seem to be very accommodating and haven’t thrown abuse at me
column29: ” she said. “I joined the Women’s Institute. I socialize with them and have a natter [long chat]. I’m having a great time. I have a new lease on life
